description.text:
This thing is a fan-powered air mixer that fits into a standard round air conditioner outlet.
These outlets use an adjustable cone to blow cold air along the ceiling, which provides a even temperature distribution in the room.
During winter however, while the aircon operates in reverse cycle for heating, this outlet arrangement only provides a hot ceiling.
The obvious solution is to remove the adjustable cone, which allows a column of warm air to exit the outlet, hit the floor and distribute across the floor. Thus achieving yet again an even room temperature.
This approach has two drawbacks - one is the noticeable column of air and the other is the somewhat industrial look of the outlet.
This fan-thing hooks into the outlet and widens the column of air, making it a lot less noticeable. It also makes the outlet look more interesting. The shown color scheme is for the kid's room. :-)

Required vitamins:
  • 608 skate bearing
    • Print the mounting bracket, the hub and 4 blades. The blades are best printed in pairs. All parts print without support. I recommend painting / dipping the blades and the mounting bracket in acetone, to increase strength. They also go shiny. Insert the bearing into the hub and clip the bracket into the bearing from the other side. Press the blades into the hub, with the thicker end pointing into the airflow.

comments.text: I worked on a very similar problem in an industrial setting where we had to expand a narrow high velocity jet of air into a slower moving, wider column of air.  What worked well was surround the duct with the cover in place with a wider duct that was as long as it was wide.

title: Z-Probe Mount w/ fine adjust flexure

description.text:
This is a mount for inductive probe used in 3D Printer bed autoleveling. I use it with a Fotek PS-05N sensor on my Voxel OX 8" 3D Printer. It has an adjustment bolt for fine tuning the z-height of your probe. The movement is possible through the use of a flexure (or compliant mechanism) that allows the sensor to move along one axis relative to the mount. With the current settings it can travel 1.5mm up or down from center. This part is designed to mount to the side of 2020 extrusion (OpenBuilds V-Slot) and extends past the end of this extrusion. To customize one, the most important setting is the distanceToMount, which is the vertical distance from the sensor mounting holes to your chassis bolt position. If you can mesure this within ~1mm accuracy the mount can adjust the rest of the way. Make this measurement while nozzle is at bed level and sensor is just barely triggered. The nut on the end of the adjustment bolt must be a lock nut(marked red in the assembly image), and is designed to spin with the bolt during adjustment. The washers on each end also facilitate this spinning. The captured nut on the flexure shuttle moves up or down as the adjustment bolt is turned. Hardware required: Sensor mounting
  • 2 M3 x 25 bolt
  • 2 M3 nuts
    • Adjustment bolt
  • 1 M3 x 30 bolt
  • 1 M3 nut
  • 1 M3 nylon lock nut
  • 2 M3 washers
    • Mount to chassis
  • 1 M5 x 8 bolt
  • 1 M5 T-slot nut
    • This part uses my linear stage flexure OpenSCAD library, more info here:
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1118407

author: Shrodix

description.text:
I wanted a way to test materials and this seemed the way - other sizes out there but what makes this one unique is it is not a perfect cube ~! ha !! Also a great way to see how well the material does bridging -- PLA is not great at bridging - It would be nice to suggest you print with the narrowest struts at the top (means the thing is taller when printed than it is wide), after printing I see it isnt possible, just print it , you can't orient it for narrow or wide because I don't think it's possible, maybe for a hypercube. Can also be used for calibration - longest struts should be 1cm, but are actually 12mm as measured on my 1st print.
2mm struts . A 1cm , 2x2 strut is the basic unit.
To test, I downloaded the cube file, printed it at 50%fill, about 210 down to 205c and .25lh.
Supposed to be about a gram and takes less than 5min.
*** I don't claim to be a mech eng. !!! I measured 12mm on longest and 10mm on shortest legs !!

title: Vanguard tripod quick release for GH-100 ball head

description.text:
I do a lot of different types of photography as a hobby, which means that I juggle several cameras around but only own one good tripod. As a result, I have an insatiable need for tripod quick releases. Instead of buying more and more quick releases for $18 a pop, I ordered some 1/4 inch quick-release screws on amazon and designed a printable version. 
This fits the Vanguard GH-100 ball head.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Whatever works best for your printer

Infill:

100%

Notes: I printed mine in PLA at 100% infill, and it is very sturdy. I would not print it at less than 100% infill for safety's sake. Remember, it's going to hold an expensive camera, so save yourself some repair money by spending an extra quarter on the print. If the clamp on the gh-100 ball head feels like it's pinching the quick release, try printing it slightly smaller (2-3% smaller).
Tap the center hole out to match the quick release screw. I didn't have the correct 1/4 inch tap for the screw, so I used a metric m6 tap to at least get a thread started.

description.text:
Nut for threaded PVC. This one is for half inch. I set the thread pitch at 1.8, which approximates 14 TPI close enough. It fits threaded riser pipe for sprinklers which are available in many short lengths for building small-ish things from 1- 4 feet in size. It also fits the various threaded PVC connectors. You can find a table of thread pitches and outside diameter for many PVC sizes here:
http://www.harvel.com/technical-support-center/dimensions-pressure-ratings/pvc-and-cpvc-threaded-pipe
You can convert SAE to metric thread pitches here: http://mdmetric.com/tech/tict.htm 3/4 inch would also use 1.8 on the thread pitch as it uses the same thread. The file could probably be trimmed down considerably by using a higher resolution number. title: Fridge door fence-post (for Whirlpool refrigerators and freezers)

description.text:
My fridge's door doesn't have much keeping things from falling off the shelves—just a single horizontal rail in front of each shelf, leaving an ample gap between the rail and the shelf. So, of course, anything smaller than that gap has a tendency to fall out when the door is opened (yay inertia!).
Hence these fence-posts, which clip on to that rail to keep stuff from falling out. Print as many as you need; you choose the spacing.
The parameters of this fence-post as supplied are fit for my Whirlpool refrigerator's shelf guardrails, which are 8 mm thick and one inch tall; you should measure your fridge's guardrails and adjust accordingly (if necessary) in the Customizer.
(Even if yours is a Whirlpool. Your model/vintage may have different guardrails.)

title: Arduino Motorized SMT Solder Paste Dispenser

description.text:
This is a motorized solder paste dispenser for soldering SMT boards that was inspired by this thing http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:384680. The home directory of this project is on github here https://github.com/zapta/misc/tree/master/paste_injector and it include hardware and firmware design of a compatible controller board that is Arduino compatible (it looks to the Arduino IDE as an Arduino Pro Mini). Schematic: https://github.com/zapta/misc/raw/master/paste_injector/eagle/paste_injector_schematic.pdf BOM: https://github.com/zapta/misc/blob/master/paste_injector/eagle/paste_injector_bom.csv EEVBLOG discussion:
http://www.eevblog.com/forum/reviews/solder-pasteflux-manual-syringe-applicator/150/ I printed successfully using both PLA and ABS and standard slicing parameters (3 layer shells, 20% infill). Hints, in assorted order:
  • When printing the motor axis coupler, make sure to have your extruder temperature high enough for a good inter layer bonding.
  • The step motor listed in the BOM is available on eBay from many sellers. They typically come with a ULN2003 driver PCB which is not needed here.
  • When mounting the coupler on the motor, try to minimize the free play along the motor axis. I used a a sharp knife to pull out the motor axis while pushing the coupler toward the motor before tightening the coupler screws.
  • You can insert the threaded inserts using any standard solder iron that fit into their holes. Preferably you will get tapered inserts similar to the ones specified in the BOM. If not, tapper them using a file or a Dremel tool. This is especially important for the insert that goes into the plunger rod. Otherwise, the internal hole hole will get clogged and the M4 threaded rod will not fit in.
  • When inserting the threaded inserts, don't push them too hard, let the heat do most of the work. This will result in better adhesion.
  • I programed the controller board using an AVRISP MKII but you can use whatever works for you. Github has the binary image file that include the Arduino bootloader and a script that programs the AVR fuses.
  • If you want to hack the firmware of the controller, solder a 6 pin header at the pads marked with FTDI and use an adapter such as FTDI Basic to hock the controller you your computer with the Arduino IDE. If you come with interesting firmware updates (e.g. having the red LED blinks proportionally to the speed), send me pull requests on github.
  • Use thin and sticky solder paste. For example Chip Quik T5. If the solder paste doesn't stick well to the PCB, dilute it as needed with IPA.
  • Avoid air bubbles in the syringe. Air bubbles makes the rate flow control more difficult.
  • The potentiometer controls the speed of the PRESS button only. I got the best results buy setting it on low and achieving a very slow rate of flow and then touching the PCB pads at a fixed rate to achieve consistent drops. This requires some practice.
  • The potentiometer is linear but the firmware does logarithmic mapping to allow very fine control at low speeds.
  • This design is specific for the BD syringe listed in the BOM. Most likely others models of syringes will not work. It requires specific dimension and rubber plunger dimensions and was design to achieve high friction between the rubber seal and the syringe's cylinder to avoid counter rotation. If you notice excessive rotation on the plastic plunger, clean the rubber seal with IPA to increase friction.
  • The controller board has a micro USB connector and operates from a standard USB charger.
  • I got good results with blunt bend 22GA Luer Lock needle. I got mine from ebay. If you want to experiment, buy an assortment of needles and see which one works for you.
  • After attaching the bent needed, you can orient the needle in the preferred direction by loosing the two syringe holder screws and rotating the syringe.
  • I use the dispenser with two hands. Right hand holds the syringe and controls the needle while the left hand presses the PUSH button as needed.
  • I attached the PCB to the motor mount using a Scotch Exterior Mounting Tape. This is a thick, heavy duty, double side tape. You don't need to cover the entire PCB, just a few small pieces will do. Make sure you have tape under the two buttons for extra support.
  • The plunger model has a small conical piece that fits at the bottom. Just glue it there before inserting it into the rubber seal. It was separated into two pieces to allow printing without material support and it eliminates the air pocket below the rubber seal (remember, air bubbles are bad).
  • Solder paste last longer when stored in a cool place. I place my dispenser in a plastic bag and put in the fridge (not the freezer). If you don't want to place the motor and electronics in the fridge, not problem, remove the two screws of the syringe holder, and turn the syringe to screw it out of the motor mount (don't pull the plunger out, this may insert air to the solder paste chamber).
  • When storing the solder paste, it's a good practice to remove the needle and close it with a Luer Lock cap, you can buy them everywhere, including amazon and ebay.
  • If you keep using the same needle (I do), make sure to clean it after each usage. I flush it using a syringe filled with IPA.
  • The PCB design currently on github (as of Nov 2015) was 100% auto routed as part of the Autorouter Challenge discussed here http://www.eevblog.com/forum/projects/the-auto-router-challenge-will-it-work/
  • The PCB currently currently on github (as of Nov 2015) uses a 'reversed' micro USB connector. This is for no specific reason, just because I have them from a previous project. Make sure to get the connector listed in the BOM or feel free to modify the PCB for your preferred micro USB connector.
  • If you are looking for PCB manufactures for your controller board you want to check prices at http://pcbshopper.com . This is 30x40mm two layer board.
  • I glued the two washers to the syringe holder using super glue. This way they don't fall off when removing the screws. Not a big deal though.
  • The 3D models were design with Openscad. This is an open source 3D programming package. If you want to tweak any dimension, load the provided .scad file in Openscad and regenerate the .stl files.

This way you can see print messages from the board and even can download a program you modify in the Arduino IDE. comments.author: merseyless

comments.text: It was this B&D 10cc. https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00FHLJUXA There are two main kind of syringe designs, the ones with the wide base (when you remove the black rubber), typically with two rings on the outside of the rubber seal and the ones with narrow base, typically with three rings. This design works with the wide base kind. The fit between the push rod and the rubber seal and between the rubber seal and the barrel need to be tight enough such that the push rod doesn't turn too much and is pushed in when the threaded rod turns. This eliminates the two stabilization rods that are used in this design http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:384680

description.text:
This model is based on the Grenadier unit from Planetary Annihilation. I like to call it the HellHound and wrote up a bit of fluff for it to make things more interesting.
The HellHound HH54AT Anti-Tank Autonomous Area Defense Robot is the ideal piece of equipment to send along with any infantry platoon that might run into armored opposition. The twin linked auto-cannons turn even the hardiest armored target into swiss cheese with ease. Commissioned originally by the United Republic of the Americas the design was mothballed due to budget concerns during the great regression and later resold to the Orbital Defense Union who saw potential in the use of robotics. The ODU used them primarily as portable turrets in colonization and assault beachhead locations during the Grajat Conflict. The three legged design gives it the added stability necessary to rapidly fire the large weaponry mounts that it comes standard with.
Standing roughly 4 meters tall (to scale) he's large enough to command authority but small enough to fit most standard commercial and military transports. This little puppy packs a wallop but won't bust your suspension when you're getting him into the field. Mobility is what he's all about. His three legs are good for a stable firing platform but they also serve to keep him moving at a steady 65kph when heading to a new firing position.
The solar system of Syrius (The Dog Star) has seen many conflicts over it's incredibly rich resources. The most recent clash saw heavy use of the HH54AT with results that speak for themselves. Once the HH54AT was in position, that ground was never retaken without orbital bombardment. This is where it earned it's nickname "The HellHound" from it's tireless work dragging the enemy back to hell. Make sure he's on your side! Order for your local militia or ground force today!

I suggest super glue for construction. See the image of the finished model for help with assembly.
** There is now an alternate leg model that skips the following steps. It is two parts but includes the FOOT, SHIN, KNEE, THIGH, and HIP models into those two parts.
First assemble the legs by attaching KNEE to THIGH. Then FOOT to SHIN. Now combine these two new pieces together for a leg. Do this THREE times.
Then attach HIP to CENTER three times. Now you can attach the three legs to the each of the three HIPs.
Attach TORSO to CENTER. Attach HEAD to TORSO. SENSORS go on the back of HEAD. SENSORS has a small pin hole for you to add a piece of paperclip or wire as an antennae or you can leave it empty.
BUTT to SHELLS and then add BARREL. There are TWO of each of these, one for left and one for right.
Attach guns to HEAD and you're done.

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Auggie's iPhone 7, 6 and 6S cradle with sound redirector amplifier Landscape and Portrait Modes.
Works both with or without cases up to 9.3 mm thick. Included are three STL versions. One with the Portrait with redirectors, one Portrait without redirectors and one with the landscape mode only if preferred.
It allows the user to watch movies while resting in bed with the sound redirected forward toward the user or for watching videos while having breakfast on a table. It also allows for browsing in portrait mode as when browsing facebook and still allows for charging and headphones if wanted.
It also works as a night table cradle to recharge overnight and to use alarm clock apps in either landscape or portrait modes.

description.text: This is a topographic map of the Palos Verdes Peninsula in the Los Angeles area of Southern California. It was generated using digital elevation model (DEM) data provided by the CIAT-CSI SRTM website (http://srtm.csi.cgiar.org).

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes: It was a bit difficult to get this to print until I used a raft so I would suggest it. This model is a hollow shell so provide support. You may have to adjust the scaling in your slicer. If you like, you can increase the z-axis disproportionately to accentuate the mountainous terrain.

RESOURCES Here are some resources to help you get the data so you can print these topo maps of most anywhere in the world. http://dwtkns.com/srtm/ http://jthatch.com/terrain2stl/ - not sure of the resolution though http://srtm.csi.cgiar.org/SELECTION/inputCoord.asp - this is what I used to get the GeoTiff files. The GeoTiff files can be opened in Blender (that's what I used) where the grayscale images are converted into height map STLs. The process I generally followed is here: https://www.matterhackers.com/news/how-to-3d-print-a-map-of-anywhere-in-the-world The Blender description on use is here: http://johnflower.org/tutorial/make-mountains-blender-height-maps
I used Blender (free) instead of 3DS Max in the example to generate the elevation image. Note that the Google Earth part does not work which is why I gave you the srtm.csi.cgiar.org link above. It took me a while to figure this all out so if you have any questions feel free to ask. With this process you should be able to print a map of anywhere.

WarGames is a favorite film of mine and I've always wanted to model the WOPR, but never quite got around to it. This weekend I came across the excellent model done by BrianEnigma and Chris25b's remix of it. After printing it out, I decided to correct the proportions that were off. STL's are hard to edit, so I started over from scratch, but I used some dimensions from the 105% WOPR Arduino case as a starting point and then went from there. It's hollow so you can put whatever you want inside of it. I think that this is the most accurate 3D model available so far and it printed beautifully. Enjoy. Special thanks to BrianEnigma, I would not have started this project if I hadn't stumbled across his. How about a nice game of chess? UPDATE: I stuck an Arduino inside with an LED board on it. It looks fantastic with the flashing lights, a little difficult to photograph unfortunately. Video available here:
https://youtu.be/8mKnKyFPGVc My wife took my original WOPR to keep on her desk at work so I built a second one using the updated r3 file. This one has a blue LOL shield inside of it instead of the original's red. https://youtu.be/iqw4kuKQveo UPDATE: r3 is a minor update of the WOPR model. Some of these new features are quite small and may not show up on lower-resolution printers. They print fine on a MakerGear M2 at 100% scale, 0.35mm nozzle.
  • Front latch positions have been moved slightly
  • Groove around small bolted hatch in front has been made thinner
  • Mouse hole added to rear for routing wires
  • Hole pattern on tall console (above where it says WOPR) has been modified to be more accurate
  • Trim groove has been added around main LED panel
  • Screw heads added to rear air vent

title: RC airplane wing skid / servo protection

description.text:
Have servos mounted under your flying wing?  
Need to protect a bottom-mounted battery pack?  
You need a couple quick and easy skids to keep your delicate parts safe.  
As provided, about 25mm from base to top, not including spikes.  3.2mm thick with 2mm thick spikes.  I printed the first one with single skin layers top and bottom, infill at 20% but it wasn't as strong as I would like (PLA).  The next few I've been printing two skin layers top/bottom with 25% infill and they're just registering about 2g each - and very strong!  
Make a slit in your foam matching the part's spikes, use CA or gorilla glue in the hole and a little on each spike.  Hold in place or use CA/kicker or hot glue to keep it from moving while it sets.  Done!

title: SCALEPRINT TUDOR TILES TT500 TO TT519

description.text:
This is the first 20 tiles that I created to make Tudor Buildings for my Tudor village that is 00 scale ( 4mm to the foot, 1:76.2) model railways. Can be also used for HO scale, British themed but could be used elsewhere.
The cover photo is of several buildings that are made using these tiles, as mentioned in other things I will upload all the printed parts to make these buildings, plus I will put together some pictures to make some other buildings I have already built. But it is best to use your own imagination to come up with your own designs. The SCALEPRINT TUDOR BUILDING SMALL TAVERN
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1116335 Is an example of what can be made from these tiles there are about 100 tiles in the set so far I will upload in lots of 20 tiles.
I have divided plastic containers that contain my tiles and I just pick them out and glue them together in the design I want, It's a bit like Lego. The building shown as the cover for the
SCALEPRINT VICTORIAN STYLE BARGE-BOARDS 45 DEGREE
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1114505 Was also made from these tiles. If you have any questions about anything I have uploaded please ask questions.
If you have a request for something I shall see what I can do, no promises though on that one.

ORD BOT HADRON MODIFIED FLASHFORGE

author: Gowans007

description.text:
i received my 3d printer recently with a spool holder that i feel can be improved even if just a little my printer came with a filament spool that had 55mm hub, later i bought 2 hatchbox rolls that had 30mm hubs, while printing they roll on an 8mm rod. this is my attempt to making a spool holder for both. i tried using a bearing at first but it failed, due to the bearing not having a cage built in.
after that i designed one with a cage, however the cage was too close to the inner and outer races so it bonded during print. so back to the drawing board. ------UPDATES----- 11/9 - edit 1:uploaded version 4 of bearing, have not tested but it should solve the original cage problem edit 2* i noticed a hiccup in repetier where the cage has a section that will still bond,therefore i do not recommend printing this yet, im currently redesigning the bearing itself. edit 3 i have uploaded spool holder version 3 with edited internals to prevent contact with the inner bearing race final edit uploaded bearing version 5 a lot less plastic but hopefully works :) 11/10 - Still haven't been home, but i just want to make it clear on the specs and how to use this, I recommend using an 8mm threaded rod, maybe 135-145mm length (I'm currently using 125mm), you may need the extra length for the 30mm hubs. The bearing-less version has a 9mm pilot hole purposely meant to allow it to float on the shaft - i recommend using washers on each side and maybe a lock nut setup(2 nuts tightened into eachother) if possible, to hold it in place. The bearing version on the other hand..... you may need to experiment with, currently up to date is the v5 bearing and the v3 spool holder, I have not had time to print this so all this is untested, except for bearing versions 1 2 and 3... which were for the most part failures...version 1 and 2 had problems where the actual ball bearings would group together causing friction, aaaaand version 3 the cage designed to prevent such issue bonded with the inner and outer race, making it 1 solid piece haha. version 4 had an issue were the bearing separator of the cage still bonded with the inner race, at least in Repetier-Host, which made me redesign the bearing to allow more space between the inner and outer races. in theory all i was going to use the same lock nut setup mentioned up top, the i made the inner race pilot hole exactly 8mm to allow some friction with the shaft, this will ensure bearing operates properly. Upload pics if you try id like to see them :) any suggestions please let me know in the comments or pm me, im all ears!

A simple mobile phone/tablet stand with 4 preset viewing angles - just rotate it round to the angle you need.
Simple, robust, and with no moving parts - any ideas for improvements just give me a shout!
--Note: I will add an upscaled version specifically for tablets; in the meantime, just scale the whole thing up by a factor of 2 (or just the x/y axis if you want it to remain a thin stand!)

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Any

Infill:

User Preference; advised 10-25%.

Notes: Print on side for best results - doesn't need supports, use raft if required - infill density and type is up to the user. If required, scale to desired size.

I wanted an easy-to-print, robust, and above all simple stand for my phone and tablet - but the only ones I could find only had one (or sometimes two) viewing angles. 
After a brief brainstorming period, it occurred to me that a right-angled triangle would provide up to four different angles with no moving parts - after that it was a simple case of adding a few stubs to stop the device slipping off and adding some pockets in the inside to reduce material usage and final weight.

This is a small chest of drawers that you can put things like Allen keys in or other tiny objects like gold doubloons. I've been working with ksuflash on trying to get Ohio Makerbot owners together and he whipped up a blog to that effect. While I was trying to design this stupid thing, I put up a post about it: http://ohio-makerbot.blogspot.com/2011/08/sneak-peek-at-my-drawers.html

If you have a printer that can do the chest in one piece, that's terrific and you'll have the best result.  My ToMs kept skipping and making a mess of things so I broke it down into chest1 & chest2 and glued the parts together.  Unfortunately, I got the length wrong.  The drawers fit, but if you print 1 chest1 and 2 chest2s you get a chest that's too long.  You can trim it down with an exacto knife which is what I did.  If you do print the chest in one piece, you'll have to sand the drawers a bit.

I don't expect anyone actually printing this but I leave it here for inspiration. A while back I added a mesh based levelling feature to Marlin. The normal bed levelling feature in Marlin was not good for my printer, first it would need some extra hardware and secondly it needs a flat surface (which i mathematically tilt) which my printer did not have because of the large build area (a RigidBot Big). The mesh method I created was very manual, and now I wanted to make it a little bit automatic. It is still a little bit manual. My idea was to keep things small and simple. So this requires mounting a switch sensor on the hotend, in my case a Pico hotend. This is my simple design of a small adapter that I glued onto a micro switch endstop. So first one move the hotend up and manually mount the sensor on the hotend. Then run the probe sequence. After that remove the sensor and run a probe to find the right Z offset. Do I need to say it should be mounted only when the hotend is cold? My Marlin repo, containing configuration for a RigidBot Big + RAMPS 1.4 + BullDog XL + Pico hotend
https://github.com/epatel/MarlinDev/commit/7613a1511983f5239c60f62613cef6e32745bde6 X carriage
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:994538 In use video
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eQUY-AaEBVE

comments.text: Can you share the offset?
comments.author: Fuganater

comments.text: Well, there is no real offset. Its more a relative distance that is calibrated in a last step where I remove the probe and then "sync" the mesh levelling grid to the nozzle.
comments.author: Fuganater

comments.text: Epatel, I did not realize you were on T-verse!  There are several users on the M2 Makergear forum using your mesh bed leveling feature and integrating it into our printers (especially those of us with large format printers).  My 400x600 printer, an MPCNC, when built as a large format 3d printer, benefits HUGELY from MBL due to the slightly flexy frame design.  Auto-probing for MBL is the feature that I have wanted, but did not realize you had been working on it! I have my MPCNC printer set up with an induction probe and MBL, so I hope I will be able to combine them for bed leveling now.  Has the MBL probe feature been integrated into the Marlin RC builds?  Thank you for continuing to improve the MBL features in Marlin.
comments.author: willnewton

comments.text:
Thanks for the comment! :) Aways great to hear people liking MBL. Think I have to checkout the M2. This probe feature will probably never be integrated into the official Marlin. But Roxy-3D has started to put in a UBL (Unified Bed Leveling) feature into Marlin, which I think merges ABL with MBL making it automatic. https://github.com/MarlinFirmware/Marlin/tree/devel-ubl
I will still be using this thing until I change printer though. Actually I added a multiple tap probing to this that I should push to github.

comments.text:
This looks really good, I am looking for a small frame for a quad build about this size, very keen to see what you do here.
Weight is critical with these things, I can do the calculations and come up with a suitable motor/ESC/Prop/battery combo.
I really like the look of this, I prefer to have replaceable arms however I am sure you are aware that would mean lots of bolts, extra weight and loss of vital internal component space. I have found that crashing a 3D printed quad busts the frame anyway so an all in one design like this is optimum. I see minimum bolts hold it together, good thing easier to pull apart and fix.
Consider a readily available type flight controller like a Nase32 or CC3D about 35mm square pcb (M3 holes that are 30.5mm apart) that needs to be centre mounted, allow it to be orientated so the USB port is accessible from either left or right hand side.
ESC's like the DYS SN20 series would be perfect in something like this.
Great job keen to make one.

title: ATOM 2.0 Nozzle Stand
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
ATOM 2.0 噴頭架 [緣起]
以前拆噴頭都是直接放在列印平台上，可是都會歪一邊，也不好施力，噴頭總是會滾來滾去。 尤其是當噴頭需要在加熱狀態下維修時更危險，
一不小心讓噴嘴壓到桌面，桌面塑膠皮就出現一個洞，也擔心一個施力不當被燙傷。 而且鎖風扇或鐵片時，一手得拿尖嘴鉗夾住防松螺母，另一手要拿六角球頭扳手鎖螺絲，還必須穩住噴頭不要亂跑，實在是件折磨人的差事。 因此常常希望有人能幫我拿著噴頭好讓我施工，最後終於有了噴頭架的構想。 [零件清單]
1.頂層噴頭架x1
2.中層置物盒x1
3.底層置物盒x1
4.支柱x3
5.置物架底板x2(選用) [功能說明]
1.可將噴頭上下顛倒，以球頭為支點放在頂層噴頭架上，讓噴頭下方顯露出來以便進行噴頭 維護/改裝 作業。
2.頂層噴頭架設有缺口，以便讓電線通過，不需將所有電線拆除才能放置噴頭。
(但由於鐵氟龍管太硬，可能會卡到中層置物架，而使噴頭無法穩定的放置，建議先將鐵氟龍管抽出後，再將噴頭放在頂層噴頭架上)
3.拆卸的螺絲配件可以暫時放在中層或底層的置物盒內，以免遺失。
4.支柱有設計2處突出點(上突出點和下突出點)，以便支撐由上向下穿入的中層置物架和頂層噴頭架，且中層置物架可以通過上突出點，不會被卡住。
5.整體高度約15公分，放在桌面時剛好可讓手肘靠在桌面上進行噴頭 維護/改裝 作業。
6.底板可依需求以不同顏色的PLA列印後放在置物盒內，可增加零件與置物盒的對比，以便於尋找零件。 [注意事項]
1.底層置物架需由下向上穿入支柱。
2.中層置物架和頂層噴頭架需由上向下穿入支柱。
3.組裝完成後，需在 噴頭架/置物架 與支柱交接處用瞬間膠固定，否則架子將會處於不穩定的狀態而無法使用。
4.底板放入置物盒後可能由於較密合而難以取出/更換，此時可用膠帶將之黏出。
5.如果是用kisslicer切片的話，請設定Inset Surface參數，以免 噴頭架/置物架 無法順利穿過支柱。

author: syp

description.text:
A work in progress attempt at making the candelabra arm hollow, for adding power wires for LED lighting. I've tried printing this, and it seems to be hollow as designed, but I can't get the only wire I've got to go all the way around all the curves. Maybe someone else will have better wire, a better print, or a cunning plan, for making it work. The hollow ends with a gap in the middle of the tab to attach to the main candelabra body - ideally, the wires should be able to rejoin the main body through that. - UPDATE [5th September] -
Two newly updated versions - both with the split tab raised up to the half-way mark. Version 07 has a ridge along the end of the tab as a support leg.
Version 08 changes the ridges to 'T' shaped, to avoid a printing island.

Print one as a test, first, to see if you can get your wires through - it's a relatively quick print (20 minutes or so on a Thingomatic).
I've got plans to attempt to stop the print before the hollow is sealed - and embed the wire in the channel to then be printed over - if you try this, please let me know in the comments!

comments.text: I sent you a message with some links to some pictures of what I had in mind to put 4 batteries (AAA) and an arduino pro mini in this puppy.  Let me know what you think.
comments.author: xnaron

comments.text: I was able to get 4 wires of 30 gauge down the hole. I have added a 3 color rgb led. I have modded the base and the middle section to take 3 maybe 4 AAA batteries. One thing I noticed on this arm is that you moved the tab down so it prints better...but it puts the arm off center. You could do this http://www.flickr.com/photos/[email protected]/6117334187/http://www.flickr.com/photos/2... My hollow arm (which sucked) had that support for printing. It worked well and you just snip the support off before attaching. Could you modify this arm to center the two tabs and add the support at the end?

comments.text: Ooh, clever.  Yes, I had to move the tab down, because (now that it has a hole in the middle) it was warping and twisting without support.

title: Folger Tech 2020 Prusa I3 dual bearing mount

description.header: Still work in progress - this is an initial design untested
description.text:
The Y carriage on the Folger Tech only has 3 bearings, This can cause vibration and rattles.
This part is to change the single side to a dual one and still use the same design and mounting holes/hardware.
This based on the model supplied by Folger.
Update 1: I've printed this and have it installed on my printer. This still allows full Y travel and makes the bed feel alot more secure. I have 1 dodgy bearing on the opposite side so can't be 100% if it removes the vibration/rattle. Will update more after bearing replacement and more testing

description.text: This is a model made in 3dsmax for a project

Notice:
~déballez
~jetez l'emballage ~(START Generate GCode) NE PAS UTILISER LE PRODUIT FINI.
OBJET PUREMENT DECORATIF

Similar to the MBlades concept: http://www.mblades.com/ This is a modification package for the Rawlings Synthetic Longsword Waster for HEMA (Historical European Martial Arts). The purpose of this modification is to create an ultra portable tool that can simulate the use of a full size sword for the purposes of solo practice.

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

20% minimum.

Notes: Some pieces need supports to print properly, I highly suggest rafts to prevent warping or the longer pieces.

Make sure to print 2 of the weight sections and the grip section. Additional supplies You'll need:
1 x M8 1.25 threaded rod (1 meter length can be cut to size with hack saw)
5 x M8 1.25 nuts
4 x M8 1.25 40mm bolds
8 x M8 washers
2 x Metal plates to act as counter weight, I used 2" wide x .25" steel bar which I cut to size and drilled holes. A Rawlings synthetics metal pommel, metal crossguard, and the rubber grip. (http://www.woodenswords.com/category_s/1837.htm) Glue pieces together and attach counter weights. Assemble the hilt.

description.text:
This is a 3D Printable Hookah/Sheesha. Anyone can print it, use it and smoke it.
PS : Be careful and choose a suitable filament.

A friend who is into puzzles pointed me at this 3D puzzle http://www.cs.tau.ac.il/~efif/applications/puzzles/knot/ so I whipped it up in a few minutes in OpenSCAD. If you get stuck, there is an animation showing the solution at http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xNtNQRTdxps

There is a sheet containing all the parts, as long as you don't mind the parts all the same color and you have a big enough print bed. Otherwise print them individually.
The parts should slide snugly through each other. If needed you can adjust the unit size and tolerance parameter in the scad file or via the thingiverse customizer.

comments.text: I love this puzzle and have already printed it twice in 2 sizes. The bigger one is all one color as I've used the "ALL" file and the other one I printed individually so I can print them in the 6 colors. I would like to make a bigger one with the 6 colors, but the .4mm tolerance makes it very sloppy on my Makerbot Replicator 2+. Is there a way to adjust the tolerances of the 6 individual pieces to print one at a time? The SCAD file only applies to the 6 pieces all at once. I'm new to 3D printing and don't pretend to know a lot about this stuff, but I'm learning. I'm sure there must have been a SCAD file for each piece, and that's what I'm looking for. Or is there a way to adjust the included SCAD file to print the pieces individually, so I can change the tolerance option? Any help would be appreciated! Thanks!
comments.author: williamcl

comments.text: If you open up the file in OpenSCAD, at bottom of the file you can see it's invoking the "printall" module to lay out all of the pieces. Just comment that out and call the piece module that you are interested in. OpenSCAD is pretty easy to get the hang of, and worth learning.

"Japanese Erasers" have been very popular with kids for a several years, as have keychains that hang in bunches on the outside of backpacks. I find both, though the erasers in particular, to be excellent 3D learning tools. When taken apart they're reduced to basic 3D shapes that can be modeled on the computer then reconstructed as 3D printed objects, which are wonderful keepsakes of their introductory modeling class. I also consider joinery to be an important early skill for young inventors to develop. So the most interesting designs in my class are those that consist of multiple pieces that are interesting whether together or as a pile of printed parts. The creation of this simple object, together with others that I've uploaded to Thingiverse, are useful exercises for anybody learning 3D modeling. Bob Krause
Inventor Studios
Berkeley, CA
my first name at inventorstudios dot com

description.text: I scanned a small pumpkin with the MakerBot Digitizer Desktop 3D Scanner.

Oye! Oye! Thanks in large part to the Thingiverse community, Zheng3 3D Printing Kickstarter #4 is fully funded! Join the Horde to be among the first humanoids to learn about the next one! We now return you to your regular model description.

"Wee yet deadly accurate, the Dryads' engines are not easily dismissed."
—Qie Zi, The Art Of Seej Weeks of intense R&D at Zheng Labs have resulted in a passel of exhausted kobolds and the Stinger Micro Ballista. The Stinger's designed for printing on tiny 3D printers; the entire engine, nock included, will easily fit on a 128x128mm build platform. Best yet: it prints in two pieces instead of four, considerably reducing one's time-to-Seej. The nock's been completely redesigned to fix a firing problem that' has plagued previous ballistae. We've also included models designed to fit both U.S. and U.K. pennies. Message Lao Zheng with dimensions if you'd like a nock that accomodates your local coinage, and we'll have the kobolds flogged until they produce what you need. This particular ballista was printed in ColorFabb Signal Yellow PLA/PHA.

description.text: I wanted to be able to securely hold a piece of copperclad to be milled into a circuit board, without needing to swap out the bed or mount. A threaded rod should be chucked in a drill and inserted in the provided holes, securing each pair of rails together.  You will need to print two of each file for a complete set.

A Sculpture found at Schwarzenbergplatz in Vienna, scanned for TU Wien - GSI

REMOVE BEFORE FLIGHT... it's used on airplanes for example on things like Pitot Covers, in order to remind the pilot to take them off before flight or they won't have an airspeed reading once they are airborne.
It's a nice thing to print with NinjaFlex or similar. I uploaded 3 files: 1- 1mm thickness
2- 2mm in thickness
(BTW if you flip the file upside down in the printing program you will have a smooth surface on the side where you can read "Remove Before Flight".) 3- Double sided 2mm thickness.
(To print the 3rd file ,the double sided one, I suggest you use a multiple of .75mm as that's the depth dimension of the writing. I used .25mm but you can use .15 or .05)
https://youtu.be/HkazwbM1BIc I will try to make a double colored one for the people who has a double extruder, but I need to look into it. Enjoy!
